html:
Onboarding, delightful copy and the element of surprise

Do you know the dinosaur?

The ‚ÄòLonely T-Rex‚Äô of Chrome.

Or perhaps you‚Äôve seen the ‚ÄòBlue screen of death‚Äô on windows.

Or maybe Apple‚Äôs ‚ÄòSpinning wheel of death‚Äô ‚ò†Ô∏è

Pre-auto save these signalled the end of the world. Lost files. Reboots. Frozen screens.

Seeing these stirs feelings of frustration and dread (as the names suggest).

These are what we call empty states.

Empty states are what you see when a page or area that could be blank. Like a search bar before you‚Äôve started searching, a chat before you‚Äôve sent a message, an error state or a new document you‚Äôve opened.

They are non-spaces where there‚Äôs technically nothing to display. As a result, these are spaces that are often overlooked in product design.

However, they‚Äôre actually incredibly important in creating positive user experiences. Why? Well, because:

  • Without them, people get confused (often thinking there‚Äôs a bug üêû)
  • They can communicate system status, giving a users a sense of control
  • They can be used to show people next steps or how to use the product in a subtle ways

According to NNGroup:

Totally empty states cause confusion about how and whether the system is working. An empty screen leaves people with questions: Is the system finished processing the request? Is content still loading? Did an error occur? Did I set the wrong filters or parameters?

The overarching goal of empty states is to build confidence that your product know‚Äôs what it‚Äôs doing, show you‚Äôre in control and show people next steps.

What better way to explore this unloved area of UX than to look at one of the best examples.

Slack.

We‚Äôll look at four types of empty states from Slack and show how they help onboarding, product adoption and reduce confusion throughout the experience, namely:

  • Feature defaults üï∫ to encourage engagement
  • First use states üê£ to onboard and activate
  • End states üéâ to congratulate and give a dopamine hit post-task
  • Error states ‚õîÔ∏è to admit when there‚Äôs been an issue and help with next steps

Before we dive in, here‚Äôs a recap of Slack‚Äôs growth from origin through unicorn, and from acquisition to now.

Slack‚Äôs rather bumpy ride from 2013 to 2025

Slack is one of the startup world‚Äôs biggest success stories, having gone from nothing to unicorn status ($1bn) in as little as 8 months.

It started as an online multiplayer game called Glitch in 2009, however the team struggled to gain traction; the game was too complex, too slow and ultimately flopped.

Instead, the team noticed that their internal communications tool they‚Äôd built to create the game was much more interesting.

And hence, Slack was born.

After launch in 2013, Slack grew 5‚Äì10% weekly in the first year and reached unicorn status not long after in 2014.

By the time I tried it first in 2019, Slack had reached 10 million daily active users.

Slack‚Äôs strong growth was due to a mix of factors: timing (as remote work grew), brand (goodbye stuffy enterprise tools, hello fun), strong backing (from Silicon Valley) and product-led growth (easy to get going and share with others).

In 2021, Salesforce bought Slack for $27.7 billion. Funnily enough, after the acquisition growth slowed. TechCrunch reported that growth dropped rapidly, from ‚Äú46% YoY in Q3 2023 to just 16% in Q4 2024.‚Äù

Nevertheless, in 2025 Slack now has 200,000 paying customers across 150 countries, including 77% of Fortune 100 companies.

Still eye-watering numbers, despite the growth slump.

I‚Äôve been using Slack for five years at this point. One of my earliest memories of the UI is the empty states in their best feature: the search bar.

Empty states in search üîé

I remember the first time Slack surprised me with its empty states. I was typing in the search bar, when I saw some entertaining copy:

‚ÄòSurely that‚Äôs around here somewhere‚Äô

Huh?

So casual. So unusual.

The next time I hit the search bar, I read:

‚ÄúSearch high and low‚Äù

The default copy in the search bar changes on each click ‚Äî it cycles through various weird, fun and (occasionally) useful copy.

It feels almost crafted instead of engineered.

What this does is two-fold:

  1. It acts as a variable reward üß† meaning that each time we visit, it‚Äôs new. Like a slot machine coaxing people back into the arcade.
  2. It creates a curiosity gap üß† where intrigue is created through riddles, gaps in information or unusual experiences, leading the customer to seek out the next step

Both of these tactics drive engagement, as well as improve awareness about the search feature.

It‚Äôs a great example of how to turn mundane UI elements into engagement opportunities and memorable micro interactions.

The injection of fun and personality into mundane, functional elements is one of the reasons Slack has been able to differentiate in a crowded market.

First use üê£ onboarding empty states

More recently, I created my own Slack workspace for the first time.

I needed to use Slack connect, and so created ‚ÄòRosie Hogggmascall‚Äôs workspace to accept invites to new clients.

It was the first time in five years I felt like I was seeing Slack with fresh eyes.

The first thing I saw was the empty states within channels.

Notice how there‚Äôs no blank page. Instead, I see activity (myself joining), templates, a welcome message and direction of what to type.

Without taking any action, my workspace feels active.

I also see that not one, but three channels have been created for me.

All with their own empty states, including:

  • Passive onboarding tips for me to get started (nothing too in-your-face)
  • Visuals to help me understand
  • Core messaging to reiterate the value of Slack
  • Default copy, helping me know what to type (üëã Hi everyone!, Roll call! Who‚Äôs here?)

The suggested actions feel subtle and easy, things like:

  • Share a GIF
  • Take a coffee break together
  • Personalise a welcome message

However they‚Äôre all driving to core actions that help you engage, onboard and get set up.

There‚Äôs even an empty state for a DM with myself.

The default copy ‚Äò‚úçÔ∏è Note to self‚Ä¶‚Äô and ‚ÄòTomorrow, I should..‚Äô makes me feel so seen, given that‚Äôs what I typically use a self-DM for in whatsapp, messenger or Slack.

What these do is avoid users drawing a blank.

Opening a new page is akin to walking through a doorway: you forget what you come for. You draw a blank.

That‚Äôs what these empty states are avoiding.

They are simultaneously:

  1. Helping you navigate a new workspace
  2. Showing you how to use features
  3. Giving you a head start by taking steps for you
  4. Avoiding writers block / blank stares
  5. Creating a sense of activity from the start

Notice how Slack anticipates and solves for common friction points before they arise.

By avoiding friction, providing structure and reducing cognitive load, Slack creates motivation and momentum that carries new users through critical activation steps (like first message and channel creation).

What‚Äôs key is that they feel helpful rather than intrusive. Instead of tooltips, repetition or popups, the use of entry states to onboard users feels like the natural flow of the product.

Cleared ‚úÖ End-goal empty states

Next up: task complete empty states.

On Slack mobile, there‚Äôs a feature called ‚Äòcatch up‚Äô.

It‚Äôs a tinder-like style summary of the messages you need to catch up on.

Once you‚Äôve swiped through your messages, you‚Äôre met with a little congratulations message.

Similar to the variable reward we saw in the search bar copy, this copy also changes every time ‚Äî moving from cool, to hype-man, to chill:

  • üòé All Clear
  • üí•Boom. You‚Äôre up to date.
  • ‚úåÔ∏èAll caught up. What‚Äôs next?
  • üçè You‚Äôve read everything you needed to. Take a moment.

(Not sure why there‚Äôs an apple there?)

Again, these small, quirky messages inject personality.

These consistent moments of personality across different features help create a cohesive brand experience, which is distinctly cooler, more casual and different from competitors (Teams would never say ‚Äòboom‚Äô‚Ä¶).

As well as being important for brand, they‚Äôre also functional. These messages signal task = complete, and provide closure. Marking the dopamine hit of a complete task creates a mini reward, reinforcing the habit loop.

Next: error states.

Uh oh ‚ò†Ô∏è error empty states

To test error states, I do two things:

  1. Turn off my wifi
  2. Search for a non-result

For the first, I see what‚Äôs called a skeleton state ‚ò†Ô∏è

It‚Äôs a loading state that shows what the UI would look like if there were results. Giving the perception that things are moving, filling the void instead of leaving it blank and removing the jump from blank white to error.

Overall, it feels less jarring and looks like the product is trying in the background, giving the labour illusion effect üß†

When I have no wifi, the empty state reads as follows:

We‚Äôre having trouble loading your workspace

This is one of those times when we‚Äôre not sure what went wrong, but we do have some suggestions that might help.

- Restart slack. Sometimes that‚Äôs all it takes

- Check the Slack service to make sure that it‚Äôs not a Slack issue

- Try our suggestions for troubleshooting connection issues

What I like here is the UX writing: clear admission that Slack doesn‚Äôt know what‚Äôs wrong and helpful advice to troubleshoot.

When I search for something that doesn‚Äôt exist, I see:

Nothing turned up

You may want to try using different keywords, checking for typos or adjusting your filters. Learn more about search

Not the results that you expected? Give feedback

Here I like the conversational language.

Users are often tired of ‚ÄòUh Oh‚Äô, or ‚ÄòOh Snap‚Äô. The new error messaging here feels almost refreshing.

Again, I‚Äôm given some helpful suggestions but note how I‚Äôm also invited to feedback. This gives the users a sense that the product is open and there‚Äôs people behind the scenes. It avoids the ‚Äòdead end‚Äô feeling of many empty states, by giving multiuple exit points.

Slack is using this real estate as an opportunity to build trust. Transforming potential areas of frustration into experiences that feel human and helpful.

Transparency + guidance = an excellent formula for an error state.

In conclusion: empty states as strategic UX

I love this example.

The devil is in the details, and once you start paying attention to empty states you see them everywhere.

What I take away from Slack is two things:

  1. Be personable: state when you don‚Äôt know, inject personality and brand voice, avoid any over-used phrases (avoid ‚Äòoh snap‚Äô like the plague). Think: how would I like to be spoken to?
  2. Be present: most importantly don‚Äôt leave a blank. Don‚Äôt leave dead-ends, or people hanging. Largely because you‚Äôre missing out on really good opportunities to drive engagement.

In terms of how to implement this, I‚Äôd suggest five steps:

  1. Audit your empty states ‚Äî map all places where users might encounter blank screens, errors, or completion states in your product journey.
  2. Add personality ‚Äî use variable rewards and conversational language that aligns with your brand to create a human connection with your users.
  3. Reduce cognitive load ‚Äî provide clear next steps, templates, structure and guidance that anticipate user needs before frustration sets in.
  4. Create momentum ‚Äî think about how you can exite people and help them get to ‚Äòaha moments‚Äô. Use empty states to guide users toward key activation actions without relying on more intrusive onboarding methods like tooltips.
  5. Be transparent‚Äî When things go wrong, be honest about what happened and provide clear paths forward. Stating the obvious can give a sense of control, which reduces doubt and helps ease frustration.

Have a go, and let me know how it goes üëÄ
